Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Plant-Herbivore Dynamics in an Herbivore-Protection Mutualism
Award.AbstractNarration:
Many mutualisms involve the exchange of a resource reward by one partner for some service by the other. Such interactions can influence the structure of ecological communities as well as the functioning of ecosystems. For example, in ant-protection mutualisms, ants protect plants or herbivores in exchange for a nectar reward. Ant mutualisms are hypothesized to have large effects on plant and herbivore species diversity and abundance. This project combines modeling and field work to explore the long-term consequences of a mutualism involving ant-protected herbivores. Understanding the feedbacks among plants, mutualistic herbivores and ants across multiple growing seasons will advance ecology by highlighting the potentially destabilizing effects of mutualisms on terrestrial ecosystems. This project brings together two researchers at a primarily undergraduate institution with a strong record of undergraduate training and incorporation of underrepresented groups in science. The proposed work will employ honors undergraduate research as its primary vehicle for outreach and training, including integrative empirical and theoretical approaches.

By definition, the short-term effect of mutualism is to increase population densities. In herbivore-protection mutualisms, this increase in population density may lead to over-exploitation of host plants in the long-term with corresponding negative consequences for protected herbivores. Preliminary results show that herbivory by the ant-protected herbivore, Publilia concava, reduces the attractiveness of its perennial host-plant, tall goldenrod, to subsequent generations. Using a two-way factorial design experiment (presence/absence of herbivores and presence/absence of ants) in two tall goldenrod field sites, this project will experimentally evaluate the consequences of the delayed herbivore effect on host-plants for host-plant selection and performance of Publilia concava. Repeated censuses of plants, herbivores, and ants over two years will document if herbivory mediates plant responses that influence herbivore performance and future host plant selection. These data will also be used to test a generalized spatial model of herbivore-protection mutualisms linking host choice behavior, induced plant resistance, and herbivore population dynamics. Results from the proposal will increase understanding of the potentially destabilizing effects of mutualism and the effect of host-choice behavior by herbivores on herbivore-plant dynamics following delayed effects of herbivory.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Mutualism are interactions between species where both partners benefit. Well known examples of mutualism include pollination and seed-dispersal while lesser known examples include cleaner fish and ant-protection mutualisms. Ant-protection mutualisms have nevertheless become model systems in studies of mutualism, primarily because it is relatively easy to manipulate ants compared to birds or flying insects such as bees. Like pollination and dispersal mutualisms, ant-protection mutualisms involve the exchange of a resource reward by one partner for some service by the other. For example, ants protect sap-feeding herbivores from their predators in exchange for a sugary reward. Ant mutualisms are hypothesized to have large effects on plant and herbivore species diversity and abundance, especially in the tropics. More generally, mutualism can influence the composition of ecological communities as well as the functioning of ecosystems. This project combined modeling and field work to explore the long-term consequences of a mutualism involving ant-protected herbivores.

By definition, the short-term effect of mutualism is to increase population densities. In ant-herbivore-protection mutualisms, this increase in population density may lead to over-exploitation of host plants in the long-term with corresponding negative consequences for protected herbivores. We tested this hypothesis using the ant-protected herbivore, Publilia concava, feeding on goldenrod, it's main host plant. To do so, we experimentally manipulated the presence of ants and herbivores in all possible combinations in "year 1" of the study. We then evaluated the host-choice behavior and survivorship of P. concava on these same plants in "year 2" of this experiment. The overall experiment was repeated twice across three years.

Our results conclusively show that the herbivore P. concava avoids laying eggs on host-plants that have a prior history of feeding. On the other hand, we found no evidence for a difference in survivorship of the developing herbivores between any of the treatments. One possible explanation for this is that oviposition choices are proportional to the underlying quality of host-plants (i.e. a host plant with twice as many resources will end up with twice the number of eggs), such that differences in oviposition choices are canceled out by differences in underlying host-plant quality.

We have begun to generalize our results from this experimental system to mutualisms in general by developing and analyzing spatially-explicit models of mutualism. Spatially-explicit models have shown that spatial patterns can emerge in biological processes ranging from gene-expression gradients during development to landscape-level species distributions. In contrast, we show that spatial patterns can not form by adding dispersal to a generalized model of our study system. Future studies will continue to evaluate the effects of density-dependent dispersal and cellular-automata-based approaches. Finally, we note that the general methodology developed in our analyses can be applied to other dynamic systems including genetic networks, chemical self-replicating artificial peptide networks, and physiological regulation.

A total of 15 undergraduates were involved with this project including two that participated in two summers. Fourteen of these students participated in a 10-week summer science program at Williams College, which included a weekly lecture by a STEM faculty, and an end-of-summer poster session open to the public. Four students used their summer research experience as the basis for a senior honors thesis, and an additional two used it as the basis for an independent project.
